name: Brooklyn Banks
description: Legendary brick banks under the Brooklyn Bridge on-ramp. One of the most iconic skate spots in history.
history: Active since the 1980s, the Banks became a global pilgrimage site. Closed during Brooklyn Bridge renovations in 2010, partially reopened, status remains contested.
bestTimes: Weekday afternoons when accessible. Check current status before visiting.
transitDirections: 4/5/6 to Brooklyn Bridge-City Hall, J/Z to Chambers St.

name: Tompkins Square Park
description: Classic East Village park with a dedicated skate-friendly vibe and smooth paths. A staple gathering spot for NYC skaters.
history: Skaters have session'd Tompkins since the 80s. The park's countercultural history and central location make it an enduring hub.
bestTimes: Afternoons and weekends year-round.
transitDirections: L to 1st Ave, 6 to Astor Place.

name: LES Skatepark
description: Official skatepark under the Manhattan Bridge. Great concrete park with a mix of street and transition elements.
history: Built in 2012 by NYC Parks with community input. Quickly became one of the city's top skateparks.
bestTimes: Early mornings for fewer crowds. Weekday sessions are mellow.
transitDirections: F to East Broadway, B/D to Grand St.

name: Chelsea Piers Skatepark
description: Indoor/covered skatepark at Chelsea Piers sports complex along the Hudson River.
history: Part of the Chelsea Piers redevelopment. Provides a sheltered option for rainy days.
bestTimes: Check hours — varies seasonally. Less crowded on weekday mornings.
transitDirections: C/E to 23rd St, walk west to the piers.

name: Astor Place
description: Iconic NYC plaza with the Alamo cube sculpture. Smooth ground and skateable ledges.
history: A staple street spot for decades. The 2016 plaza renovation added smoother surfaces.
bestTimes: Late evenings and weekends. Can get busy with pedestrians during the day.
transitDirections: 6 to Astor Place, N/R to 8th St-NYU.

name: Federal Plaza
description: Massive government plaza with perfect granite ledges. Heavily skated in videos but security is aggressive.
history: Featured in countless skate videos since the 90s. Security enforcement has increased over the years.
bestTimes: Weekends and after-hours when security is lighter.
transitDirections: 4/5/6 to Brooklyn Bridge-City Hall, J/Z to Chambers.

name: Owl's Head Skatepark
description: Well-built concrete park in Owl's Head Park overlooking the harbor. One of Brooklyn's best skateparks.
history: Opened around 2013, designed with community skater input. Strong local scene.
bestTimes: Mornings for a chill session. Weekends get packed.
transitDirections: R to Bay Ridge Ave, walk to Owl's Head Park.

name: McCarren Skatepark
description: Popular Williamsburg skatepark in McCarren Park. Great street-style layout.
history: Opened 2010, part of the McCarren Park renovation. Central to the Williamsburg skate scene.
bestTimes: Afternoons. Gets crowded on nice-weather weekends.
transitDirections: L to Bedford Ave or G to Nassau Ave.

name: DUMBO Skate Spot
description: Cobblestone-adjacent flat areas under the Manhattan Bridge in DUMBO with various skateable architecture.
history: Organic street spot that grew as DUMBO developed. The waterfront area provides scenic sessions.
bestTimes: Weekday mornings before tourists arrive.
transitDirections: F to York St, A/C to High St.

name: Prospect Park Skate Circle
description: Smooth park loops and the skate circle area near the bandshell. Great for cruising and flat ground tricks.
history: Skaters and rollerbladers have used the park paths for decades. The skate circle is a weekend tradition.
bestTimes: Weekend afternoons for the social scene. Weekdays for peaceful cruising.
transitDirections: B/Q to Prospect Park, 2/3 to Grand Army Plaza.

name: Flushing Meadows Skatepark
description: Large concrete skatepark in Flushing Meadows Corona Park near the Unisphere.
history: Built as part of park improvements. Serves the large Queens skating community.
bestTimes: Afternoons. The park is huge so it rarely feels overcrowded.
transitDirections: 7 to Mets-Willets Point.

name: Rockaway Beach Skatepark
description: Beachside bowl-heavy park with deep transition. One of the gnarliest parks in NYC.
history: Community-driven build on the Rockaway boardwalk. Attracts serious transition skaters.
bestTimes: Summer mornings — combine with a beach day. Off-season weekdays are empty.
transitDirections: A to Rockaway Beach stations, or ferry to Rockaway.

name: Astoria Park Skatepark
description: Solid neighborhood skatepark under the Hell Gate Bridge in Astoria Park.
history: Added during park renovations. Serves the growing Astoria skate community.
bestTimes: Afternoons year-round. Good local vibe.
transitDirections: N/W to Astoria Blvd, walk to Astoria Park.

name: Mullaly Skatepark
description: One of the best skateparks in NYC — deep bowls, great flow, and a solid street section. The Bronx's crown jewel.
history: Built in 2009–2010, designed by California Skateparks. Widely praised for its quality and flow.
bestTimes: Weekday afternoons for shorter waits on the bowl.
transitDirections: B/D/4 to 161st St-Yankee Stadium, walk north.

name: River Park Skatepark
description: Neighborhood park along the Bronx River with a compact but fun skate area.
history: Part of South Bronx greenway improvements. Provides much-needed skate infrastructure.
bestTimes: Afternoons. Quiet on weekdays.
transitDirections: 6 to Brook Ave or 2/5 to 3rd Ave-149th St.

name: Stapleton Skatepark
description: Staten Island's primary skatepark near the waterfront. Compact street-style layout.
history: Community-funded and built to serve Staten Island skaters who otherwise had to ferry to Brooklyn or Manhattan.
bestTimes: Weekends for the local crew. Weekdays are empty.
transitDirections: Staten Island Ferry + S51/S81 bus to Stapleton.

name: Pier 62 Skatepark
description: Free public skatepark on Pier 62 in Hudson River Park. Great river views and solid design.
history: Opened 2010 as part of Hudson River Park. Designed with input from local skaters.
bestTimes: Early mornings or late evenings. Midday gets busy with tourists.
transitDirections: C/E to 23rd St, walk west. 1 to 23rd St.

name: Cooper Park Skatepark
description: Neighborhood skatepark in Cooper Park. Small but well-maintained with a friendly local scene.
history: Added during Cooper Park renovations. Popular with the East Williamsburg and Bushwick skating community.
bestTimes: Afternoons and weekends.
transitDirections: L to Grand St or Morgan Ave.

name: Washington Heights Banks
description: Steep streets and concrete banks in the Heights. Raw street skating with amazing hill bombs.
history: Uptown street spots that have been session'd by local crews for years. Less documented than downtown spots.
bestTimes: Afternoons. Traffic is lighter on weekends.
transitDirections: A/C to 168th St or 1 to 168th St.

name: Red Hook DIY Spot
description: Community-built DIY spot in Red Hook's industrial waterfront area. Raw, creative, and constantly evolving.
history: Built and maintained by local skaters using found materials. Embodies the DIY skate spirit.
bestTimes: Weekends when the crew is building and skating.
transitDirections: F/G to Smith-9th St, walk south. B61 bus.

name: Midtown Courthouse Banks
description: Marble banks and ledges around Midtown courthouses. Classic spot but heavy security.
history: Featured in many NYC skate videos. Security crackdowns have made sessions rare.
bestTimes: Very early mornings or late nights only.
transitDirections: 4/5/6/7/S to Grand Central.

name: Hunts Point DIY
description: Bronx DIY spot built by local skaters in Hunts Point industrial area. Gritty and authentic.
history: Started as an abandoned lot turned skate haven. Community maintains and evolves it.
bestTimes: Weekends when crews are active.
transitDirections: 6 to Hunts Point Ave.

name: Freshkills Skatepark
description: Modern skatepark built on the transformed Freshkills landfill site. Clean concrete with a mix of transition and street features.
history: Part of the massive Freshkills Park redevelopment, opened as one of the newest parks on the island.
bestTimes: Weekend mornings before crowds. Great in fall.
transitDirections: SIR to Richmond Valley, then S74 bus. Or drive — parking available.

name: Faber Park Banks
description: Mellow banks and smooth ledges in a quiet park setting. Low-key spot that rarely gets crowded.
history: A local favorite since the early 2000s. The concrete banks were originally landscaping features that skaters adopted.
bestTimes: Anytime — this spot is rarely busy.
transitDirections: SIR to Port Richmond, short walk north.

name: Midland Beach Skatepark
description: Beachside skatepark with ocean breezes and a solid mix of street and transition elements.
history: Community-funded park that opened after years of petitioning by local skaters.
bestTimes: Late afternoon — catch the sunset while you session.
transitDirections: S51 bus to Midland Ave, walk toward the beach.

name: South Beach DIY
description: Gritty DIY spot under the expressway overpass. Raw concrete and creative obstacles built by locals.
history: Built organically by Staten Island skaters who needed a covered spot for rainy days. Constantly evolving.
bestTimes: Works in rain thanks to overhead cover. Best on weekday evenings.
transitDirections: S51 bus to Father Capodanno Blvd, walk under the overpass.

name: Maloof Skatepark
description: World-class skatepark designed by California Skateparks. Deep bowl, flowing snake run, and technical street section.
history: Built with backing from the Maloof family (of Maloof Money Cup fame). One of the premier parks in the outer boroughs.
bestTimes: Early mornings on weekdays. Competition-level park gets packed on weekends.
transitDirections: 7 train to Flushing-Main St, then Q65 bus.

name: Far Rockaway Skatepark
description: Beachfront skatepark steps from the Atlantic Ocean. Chill vibes with a good mix of features for all levels.
history: Part of the Rockaway Beach revitalization. A welcome addition to the surf-and-skate culture of the peninsula.
bestTimes: Summer mornings — skate then surf. Off-season is empty and perfect.
transitDirections: A train to Far Rockaway-Mott Ave, walk south to the beach.

name: Pelham Bay Skatepark
description: Solid neighborhood park near Pelham Bay Park with a good flow layout and smooth concrete.
history: Built as part of NYC Parks' initiative to add skateparks to every borough. Serves the northeast Bronx skating community.
bestTimes: Weekday afternoons. Quiet spot that never gets too packed.
transitDirections: 6 train to Pelham Bay Park, short walk east.

name: Poe Park Banks
description: Natural banks and granite ledges in the park surrounding the Edgar Allan Poe Cottage. Smooth ground for flatground tricks.
history: Skaters have been hitting the banks here since the 90s. The park renovation actually made the spots better.
bestTimes: Weekday afternoons. Avoid weekends when the park is busy with families.
transitDirections: D train to Kingsbridge Rd, walk east to Grand Concourse.

name: Riverside Skatepark
description: Riverside Park's hidden gem — a well-maintained skatepark overlooking the Hudson River.
history: Opened in the 2010s as part of Riverside Park South expansion. Quickly became a UWS staple.
bestTimes: Golden hour sessions with Hudson River sunsets are unbeatable.
transitDirections: 1 train to 103rd St, walk west to the park.

name: Coleman Playground Skatepark
description: Uptown skatepark in Washington Heights with a tight but fun layout. Strong local scene.
history: Grassroots effort by uptown skaters brought this park to life. Represents the growing skate culture north of 125th.
bestTimes: After school hours for the local crew. Weekday mornings for solo sessions.
transitDirections: A train to 175th St, walk east.

name: Columbus Park Benches
description: Smooth marble benches and granite ledges in the heart of Chinatown. Classic NYC street skating.
history: A staple of the downtown skate scene. Featured in countless video parts from Zoo York and Supreme riders.
bestTimes: Early mornings before the park fills up with tai chi groups.
transitDirections: J/Z to Chambers St or N/Q/R/W to Canal St.

name: Harlem River Park Banks
description: Steep banks along the Harlem River with raw street spots scattered throughout. Not for beginners.
history: Discovered by uptown crews in the late 2000s. Still relatively unknown to the broader scene.
bestTimes: Weekday afternoons. Bring wax — the ledges need love.
transitDirections: 2/3 to 135th St, walk east to the river.

name: Industry City Banks
description: Repurposed industrial complex with butter-smooth ground, mellow banks, and endless ledge lines.
history: As Industry City gentrified, skaters discovered the perfect smooth concrete and architectural features. A modern classic.
bestTimes: Weekday evenings after businesses close. Weekend mornings work too.
transitDirections: D/N/R to 36th St, walk west toward the waterfront.

name: Greenpoint Skatepark
description: Compact but well-designed park in the heart of Greenpoint. Strong local scene and good vibes.
history: Part of the Greenpoint waterfront redevelopment. Filled a gap in north Brooklyn's skate infrastructure.
bestTimes: Weekend mornings for a mellow session. Weekday evenings for the local crew.
transitDirections: G train to Greenpoint Ave, walk north.

name: Bed-Stuy DIY Spot
description: Community-built DIY spot under the J/M tracks. Raw, creative, and constantly evolving.
history: Started as a few poured ledges in an empty lot. The Bed-Stuy skate community has built it into a full-featured spot over several years.
bestTimes: Weekday evenings. Weekend afternoon sessions often have BBQs.
transitDirections: J/M to Myrtle-Broadway, walk south on Broadway.

name: Coney Island Skatepark
description: Boardwalk-adjacent skatepark with ocean views. Skate, then hit the beach or grab a Nathan's dog.
history: Opened as part of Coney Island's revitalization. Brings together the beach culture and skate scene perfectly.
bestTimes: Summer mornings — skate before the beach crowds arrive. Off-season is empty paradise.
transitDirections: D/F/N/Q to Coney Island-Stillwell Ave.

name: The Cube (Astor Place)
description: The iconic Alamo cube sculpture plaza — ultra-smooth ground perfect for flatground sessions and filming.
history: A gathering point for NYC skaters since the 80s. The smooth plaza surface has hosted countless video parts.
bestTimes: Late night for empty sessions. Daytime is busy but rideable.
transitDirections: 6 to Astor Place or N/R/W to 8th St-NYU.

name: Bronx River Skatepark
description: Spacious skatepark along the Bronx River Greenway. Room to ride with a diverse set of features.
history: Part of the Bronx River corridor revitalization, giving South Bronx skaters a proper home park.
bestTimes: Weekday mornings — almost always empty. Great after school on weekdays too.
transitDirections: 2/5 to East 174th St, walk east to the greenway.

name: Springfield Park Spot
description: Southeast Queens hidden gem with smooth ledges and natural banks throughout the park.
history: Local skaters in Springfield Gardens built a scene here away from the usual Queens spots.
bestTimes: Weekend mornings. Peaceful and uncrowded.
transitDirections: LIRR to Laurelton or Q5 bus to Springfield Blvd.

name: Williamsburg Bridge Banks
description: Raw street spot under the Williamsburg Bridge approach. Steep banks and crusty ledges — not for the faint of heart.
history: Old-school BK spot that's been sessioned since the early 2000s. Zoo York and DGK riders filmed here.
bestTimes: Anytime — it's under a bridge. Best on dry weekdays.
transitDirections: J/M/Z to Marcy Ave, walk toward the bridge.
